Football, soccer, and boxing all come with a high risk of repeated head injuries, and research demonstrates that those head injuries can have lifetime effects. Some players in these high-impact sports develop [[☃ definition 1]], a condition where repeated [[☃ definition 3]] result in tangles of a protein called tau building up in the brain. CTE can harm memory, thinking, and planning skills, and can even lead to death. 

A study examining the brains of 631 former football players revealed that 180 of them had no signs of CTE, 163 had signs of low-level CTE, and 288 had high-level CTE. Another study found that 345 out of 376 former [[☃ definition 2]] players had CTE. 

Thankfully, most individuals who go on to develop CTE have limited or no symptoms. And while scientists may not have found a cure for the condition yet, they’re keeping their eyes on the ball, searching for the treatment that may save thousands of lives.
